metadata./Title: Circulatory characteristics of early mobilization after surgery for bilateral pheochromocytoma: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Surgical treatment of pheochromocytomas is associated with circulatory dynamics instability, necessitating systemic management of the patient in the intensive care unit after surgery. Early mobilization after pheo chromocytoma surgery is not described in the guidelines, and to our knowledge, no reports have specifically focused 
on circulatory dynamics during early mobilization after surgery.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 31-year-old Japanese woman was diagnosed with bilateral pheochromocytoma and under went a second-stage adrenalectomy for bilateral pheochromocytoma at our hospital. We evaluated circulatory 
dynamics during a passive upright posture on postoperative days 1 and 4. She was placed on a tilt bed in the supine 
position (0° head) for 15 min, passive upright posture (60°) for 15 min, and supine position again for 10 min. In 
the passive upright posture, both systolic and diastolic blood pressure decreased, and the heart rate increased 
by 10 bpm over approximately 10 minutes. After the postural change from the passive upright posture to the supine 
position, the heart rate decreased to a level lower than in the supine prior to the passive upright posture. The same 
measurements were taken on postoperative day 4. Systolic blood pressure decreased in the passive upright posture, 
but diastolic blood pressure remained unchanged. The heart rate also increased earlier after passive upright posture 
compared with that on the day after surgery. When the patient returned to the supine position from the passive 
upright posture, the heart rate decreased even further compared with its level prior to the passive upright posture, 
as observed on the day after surgery.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Circulatory dynamics may fluctuate after surgery for pheochromocytoma due to a relative decrease 
in epinephrine and norepinephrine secretion. In this case, the patient’s response may be close to normal by the fourth 
postoperative day, but circulatory dynamics fluctuations were noted on both the first and fourth postoperative days 
when the patient was supine after passive upright posture. Although the substantial variability of perioperative 
circulatory dynamics in patients with pheochromocytoma has improved considerably with the development of perio perative management guidelines, circulatory dynamics should be carefully monitored during early mobilization 
and after its completion.

Background
Pheochromocytomas are adrenal tumors with endocrine 
activity. Surgical treatment often
sections.Results:
results in hemody namic instability. Intraoperatively, the hypersecretion of 
catecholamines in response to stimuli leads to surgeryinduced hypertension, whereas a rapid decrease in blood 
catecholamines post tumor resection triggers hemody namic instability, such as hypotension [1]. Therefore, 
careful monitoring and adjustment of intravenous fluids 
and circulatory medications are essential both intraop eratively and postoperatively. Advances in perioperative 
management through the development of guidelines have 
significantly reduced perioperative complications [2, 3].
Systemic management of the patient in the intensive 
care unit (ICU) is required after surgical treatment of 
pheochromocytoma [1]. Early mobilization is a crucial 
component of systemic ICU management and improves 
functional independence at discharge for postsurgi cal patients [4]. Orthostatic tolerance is important for 
early mobilization in postoperative patients, and cardiac 
monitoring is necessary because of the risk of cardiac 
fluctuations during early mobilization [5–7]. However, 
early mobilization after pheochromocytoma surgery, 
which may cause circulatory fluctuations, has not been 
described in current guidelines. To our knowledge, no 
studies have specifically examined circulatory dynam ics during early mobilization after surgery. The safety 
of early mobilization after pheochromocytoma surgery 
remains unknown [2, 3].
This case report evaluates the circulatory dynam ics during early mobilization on postoperative days 1 
and 4 in a patient who underwent second-stage adrenal 
tumor resection for bilateral pheochromocytomas at our 
hospital.
Case presentation
Preoperative management
A 31-year-old Japanese woman presented to our hospi tal. She was diagnosed with medullary thyroid cancer 
and underwent a total thyroidectomy three times at the 
ages of 11, 19, and 20  years and was placed on regular 
levothyroxine sodium therapy. Genetic testing revealed 
a diagnosis of MEN2A associated with a RET  patho logical variant of exon 11 codon 634, and she was being 
followed up. Her father was also identified with a RET  
mutation and diagnosed with MEN2A, but her sister 
did not show the same mutation. Although she did not 
exhibit any obvious symptoms, a follow-up computed 
tomography (CT) scan conducted a year before the sur gery detected bilateral adrenal masses, up to 60  mm in 
size and arranged in a rosary-like pattern. Subsequent 
evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral pheochro mocytomas. Subsequently, she underwent laparoscopic left adrenal tumor resection  9  months prior to the cur rent surgery. All diagnoses and treatments were con ducted at Hiroshima University Hospital. Analysis of 24 h 
urine collected before the left adrenalectomy revealed 
86.4  μg/day of epinephrine (3.0–41.0), 297.6  μg/day of 
norepinephrine (31.0–160.0), 1177.6 μg/day of dopamine 
(280.0–1100.0), 1.87  mg/day of metanephrine (0.04–
0.18), and 2.22  mg/day normetanephrine (0.10–0.28), 
indicating catecholamine overproduction. After the left 
adrenalectomy, her 24  h urine revealed 40.0  μg/day of 
epinephrine (3.0–41.0), 244.2  μg/day of norepinephrine 
(31.0–160.0), 1263.5 μg/day of dopamine (280.0–1100.0), 
0.99 mg/day of metanephrine (0.04–0.18), and 1.20 mg/
day of normetanephrine (0.10–0.28). Given the persistent 
elevated catecholamine production, an additional right 
adrenalectomy was considered necessary. Preoperative 
magnetic resonance imaging revealed two masses, each 
less than 3 cm in diameter, on the cephalocaudal side of 
the right adrenal gland and a structure on the dorsal side 
that appeared to be a normal adrenal gland, prompting 
us to schedule a robot-assisted right adrenalectomy. One 
week prior to surgery, the patient received doxazosin 
(16 mg/day) for blood pressure (BP) control and bisopr olol fumarate hydrochloride (2.5  mg/day) for heart rate 
(HR) control. Additionally, she was encouraged to con sume fluids and salt.
There were no problems with economic or cultural 
barriers affecting the diagnostic process or patient 
management.
Operative findings
A robot-assisted right adrenalectomy was performed 
transperitoneally using a da Vinci Xi platform. Preop erative imaging revealed a mass <3  cm in size on the 
cephalocaudal side of the right adrenal gland. The bor der between the mass and the normal adrenal gland was 
indistinct, and a new small nodule was found near the 
mass on the caudal side. Consequently, total resection 
was performed as planned.
Anesthesia was induced by total intravenous anesthesia 
with propofol, remifentanil, and rocuronium. An epidural 
analgesic catheter was placed from Th11/12 prior to 
induction of anesthesia. Maintenance was provided with 
target-controlled infusion of propofol (2.5  µg/mL) and 
remifentanil (0.2 µg/kg/minute). No epidural was admin istered intraoperatively. Immediately prior to surgery, 
the HR was 55 bpm, and the BP was 90/50 mmHg. After 
the start of insufflation, a gradual increase in HR and 
BP was observed, temporarily reaching a maximum HR 
of 130  bpm and BP of 190/90  mmHg. However, except 
for a total of 0.6 mg intravenous nicardipine, no circula tory agonists were used intraoperatively, and HR and BP 
were generally maintained at 100 bpm and 150/65 mmHg

(respectively) during pneumoperitoneum. HR and BP 
recovered to resting values with tumor resection. Opera tive time was 2 hours and 26 minutes and anesthesia time 
was 3 hours and 52 minutes. The patient was extubated 
in the operating room and admitted to the surgical inten sive care unit (SICU) after surgery.
Postoperative course
The patient was extubated in the operating room and 
postoperatively admitted to the SICU. The anesthesia 
time was 3 hours and 52 minutes, the operative time was 
2 hours and 26 minutes, and the robotic time was 1 hour 
and 48 minutes. No catecholamine was required during 
any phase of the perioperative period.
Intraoperatively, the patient was under general anes thesia, and continuous epidural anesthesia with 0.133% 
ropivacaine (4 mL/hour) was administered for 39 hours 
after surgery, providing effective analgesia. In addition, 
intravenous administration of 1000  mg acetaminophen 
and 50  mg flurbiprofen axetil were given on postopera tive day 1, and 60  mg of oral loxoprofen was added on 
postoperative day 2 for pain management. Postoperative 
steroid management included hydrocortisone 250  mg/
day intravenously on the day of surgery, hydrocortisone 
30 mg/day on postoperative days 1 and 2, hydrocortisone 
20 mg/day on postoperative days 3 and 4, and hydrocorti sone 15 mg/day orally on postoperative day 5.
The intraoperative in–out balance was +1802  mL, 
including 33 mL of blood loss and 265 mL of urine loss. 
The ureter was removed on the first postoperative day, 
and the patient was started on a free diet that morning.
Early mobilization was initiated by a physical therapist. 
The patient was informed that early mobilization would 
be performed from the time of admission to the SICU. 
For safety reasons, she also agreed to use a tilt bed for 
rigorous assessment of circulatory dynamics. The circula tory dynamics were evaluated in the passive upright pos ture using a tilt bed on the first and fourth postoperative 
day (Fig. 1).
Rehabilitation
Given the expected hypotension due to decreased cat echolamine levels, gradual early mobilization was initi ated on the first postoperative day using a tilt bed with 
the Sara  Combilizer® (Arjo AB, Sweden) in the passive 
standing position (Fig.  2). Early mobilization comprised 
15  minutes of rest in the supine position (0° head posi tion), 15 minutes in the passive upright posture (60°), and 
10 minutes back in the supine position (0° head position).
On the first postoperative day, the following param eters were measured every minute using a bedside medi cal device  (Intellivue®, Philips, Japan) and automatically 
stored in an ICU information system (Fortec  ACSYS®, Philips, Japan): HR, systolic BP (SBP), diastolic BP (DBP), 
mean BP (MBP), respiratory rate (RR), and peripheral 
oxygen saturation  (SpO2). In addition, stroke volume 
variation, continuous cardiac index (CCI), left ventricu lar systolic index, and systemic vascular resistance index 
(SVRI) were measured using the Pulsioflex PC4000 ver. 
4.0 (Pulsion Medical System, Munich, Germany). Con tinuous values were averaged every 3  minutes. Central 
venous pressure (CVP) was measured twice in the supine 
position before passive upright posture with a time delay, 
and both measurements were 7 mmHg. Pain was assessed 
using the numeric rating scale (NRS) twice at rest, twice 
in the upright posture, and twice after termination of the 
passive upright posture. During upright postural conver sion, the transducer position was adjusted to the level of 
the right atrium using the intersection of the midaxillary 
line and fourth intercostal space as a landmark.
The patient was discharged from the SICU 21 h postop eratively. On postoperative day 4 (99 hours after admis sion), the same measurements were performed on a tilt 
bed; assessments were made intermittently every minute 
and averaged every 3 min. The parameters included HR, 
SBP , DBP , MBP , RR, and  SpO2. Pain at the surgical wound 
site was assessed using the NRS twice at rest, twice in an 
upright posture, and once at the end of the procedure. 
Physical function was assessed on postoperative day 4.
Atrial fibrillation or extrasystoles were not observed 
during bed rest, and various parameters were con tinuously measured. Twenty hours after surgery in the 
SICU, changes in circulatory dynamics were observed 
during early mobilization using the tilt bed (Figs.  3 and 
4; Table  1). In the upright position, the NRS score for 
pain remained at 1, SBP and DBP decreased, and HR 
increased by 10 bpm over approximately 10 minutes. The 
HR remained lower than that in the original supine posi tion for a few minutes.
The patient was discharged from the SICU 21  hours 
postoperatively and began ambulation the next day 
(25 hours postoperatively) in the general ward. On post operative day 4 (99  hours postoperatively), the patient 
was positioned upright using the tilt bed, and cardiody namic changes are shown in Fig.  5 and Table  2. The HR 
increased early after assuming the upright posture. Upon 
returning to the supine position after the passive upright 
posture, the HR decreased compared with its level prior 
to assuming the passive upright posture, similar to the 
pattern observed on the day after surgery.
On postoperative day 4 (99  hours after admission), 
her grip strength was 25.9  kg on the right and 23.3  kg 
on the left, her 10 m walking time was 7.78 seconds, and 
her short performance physical battery score (4 m walk ing for 3.91  seconds, tandem standing for 10  seconds, 
five times standing for 8.63  seconds) was 12 out of 12.

The patient was discharged home on postoperative day 
5 (117  hours after admission). Postoperative urinary 
catecholamine metabolites were within normal lim its (metanephrine < 0.01  mg/g Cre, normetanephrine 
0.23 mg/g Cre).
sections.Discussion:
Discussion and conclusion
In this case, we observed the patient in an upright pos ture on a tilt bed to evaluate the circulatory dynamics 
associated with early mobilization of a patient immedi ately after surgery for bilateral adrenal pheochromocy toma on postoperative days 1 and 4. An upright posture for 5  minutes is recommended to observe the response 
to orthostatic hypotension [8, 9]. In this case, the patient 
remained in an upright posture for 15 minutes, which is 
sufficient for interpreting the results. A tilt bed can easily 
organize drains, and its safety and effectiveness in early 
mobilization have been reported [10, 11]. Furthermore, 
we used a tilt table because it eliminates the effects of 
wound pain associated with body movements on circula tory dynamics.
In a study of 470 healthy participants, the circula tory dynamics during 5  minutes of supine posture, 
5  minutes of upright posture at 60°, and 5  minutes of

supine posture showed that SBP increases slowly after 
a decrease of 5–10  mmHg, and DBP increases by 
5  mmHg immediately after a decrease of 2–3  mmHg 
in the upright posture [9 ]. In a similar study compris ing 179 participants, HR increased by 10–15 bpm after 
a few minutes in an upright posture [12]. Furthermore, 
upright posture decreased CCI by approximately 10% 
from 2.8 to 2.5  mL/minutes/m2 and increased SVRI 
from 2100 to 2400 (dyn  ×  seconds/cm5 ×  m2) [12]. 
After passive upright posture, there is a decrease in SBP 
and an increase in HR in normal subjects. The increase 
in HR induced by passive upright posture is biphasic 
in nature. Initially, parasympathetic inhibition causes 
an increase in HR, but this is very brief and essentially sympathetic stimulation is the primary mechanism [13]. 
This compensatory HR response can be interpreted as 
a result of sympathetic activation with increased nor epinephrine secretion and consequent vasoconstriction 
and increased HR. In this case, a gradual decrease in BP 
was observed on postoperative day 1, when the patient 
was in an upright posture. SBP decreased by approxi mately 20 mmHg, and DBP decreased by approximately 
10 mmHg over a period of 15 min. Although there was 
an increase in HR by approximately 5–10  bpm, the 
response was very slow. Additionally, a ΔHR/ΔSBP 
value of less than 0.5 indicates neurogenic hypotension 
[14]. The very slow increase in HR despite hypotension 
in this case, along with a ΔHR/ΔSBP value of less than 
0.5 at 6  minutes after assuming an upright posture, 
strongly suggests that there is also inadequate activa tion of the sympathetic nervous system. Furthermore, 
during the tilt test on postoperative day 1, both SBP 
and DBP decreased, likely due to reduced peripheral 
vascular resistance. Although HR and CCI increased, 
SVRI decreased, indicating a decrease in α-stimulation. 
Additionally, the slow response in HR suggests a 
decrease in β-stimulation as well. This could be attrib uted to a relative decrease in norepinephrine secretion. 
The patient was able to begin gait practice on postop erative day 1 because there was no extreme drop in BP 
that would have led to impaired consciousness.
The patient’s progress was good; she was discharged 
home on postoperative day 5. A passive upright posture 
using a tilt bed was performed again on postoperative 
day 4. On postoperative day 4, there was an immedi ate 20 mmHg drop in SBP but not DBP after assuming 
the upright posture, and a compensatory change due 
to a rapid increase in HR was observed. This is simi lar to the α and β effects seen in healthy individuals. 
Notably, on postoperative days 1 and 4, the HR and 
CCI were lower in the supine position after assum ing the upright tilt posture compared with the supine 
posture before assuming the upright posture. CCI is a 
measure of cardiac output corrected for body surface 
area and assesses the overall pumping capacity and per fusion of the heart. Previous studies have shown that 
parasympathetic activity fluctuates in the supine posi tion after assuming an upright posture compared with 
before assuming an upright posture [15]. While HR 
was similar to that before assuming an upright posture 
in a previous study, a decrease in HR was induced in 
this case. This suggests fluctuations in cardiac parasym pathetic activity. In clinical practice, attention should 
be paid to the possibility of bradycardia attacks after 
early mobilization. To the best of our knowledge, there 
are no reports on early mobilization after surgery for

Methods of assessment of circulatory dynamics during early 
mobilization after pheochromocytoma surgery. Early mobilization 
was started gradually by using a tilt bed with Sara  Combilizer® (Arjo 
AB, Sweden) in passive upright posture from the first postoperative 
day. Early mobilization consisted of 15 minutes of rest in the supine 
position (0° head position), 15 minutes in the passive upright posture 
(60°), and 10 minutes of rest back in the supine position (0° head 
position). A bedside medical device  (Intellivue®, Philips, Japan) 
and Pulsioflex PC4000 ver. 4.0 (Pulsion Medical System, Munich, 
Germany) were used to evaluate various circulatory dynamics 
parameters. During upright postural conversion, the transducer 
position was adjusted to the level of the right atrium using 
the intersection of the midaxillary line and fourth intercostal space 
as a landmark

be excluded that early mobilization may be influenced

This study has limitations that should be addressed in 
future research. First, the findings are based on a single 
case, which restricts the generalizability of the results. 
The short observation period, monitoring circulatory 
dynamics only on postoperative days 1 and 4, may not 
fully capture the full range of postoperative fluctuations 
experienced by patients. Another limitation is the use of 
continuous epidural analgesia postoperatively, which can cause a decrease in BP due to vasodilation. Therefore, it 
cannot be ruled out that the circulatory index measured 
in the passive upright posture may have been influenced 
in this case. If abnormal hypotension is observed, it may 
be necessary to consider interrupting epidural analge sia. However, in this particular case, epidural analgesia 
did not cause abnormal hypotension, and its effect was 
limited.

their generalizability. Extending the monitoring period 
of circulatory dynamics over a longer postoperative 
timeframe would provide a more comprehensive under standing of the long-term effects of early mobilization. 
Comparative studies should be conducted to evaluate 
different methods of early mobilization, identifying the 
safest and most effective approaches for patients under going surgery for pheochromocytoma. Additionally, 
multicenter studies could help account for variations in 
surgical and postoperative management practices, pro viding a more robust dataset. Finally, controlling for and 
analyzing the impact of potential confounding factors, 
such as the type and duration of anesthesia, would offer 
a clearer understanding of their effects on circulatory 
dynamics during early mobilization.The perioperative 
management of pheochromocytoma has significantly 
improved with the development of guidelines, resulting 
in a substantial reduction in perioperative circulatory 
fluctuations. In the case reported here, due to strict pre operative management, the patient’s circulatory dynam ics stabilized approximately 1  week after surgery. As a 
result, the patient regained the ability to perform activi ties of daily living and was subsequently discharged. In 
this case, the patient’s response appeared to be close to 
normal by the fourth postoperative day. It is important to 
note the fluctuations in circulatory dynamics on both the 
first and fourth postoperative days, particularly when the 
patient is in a supine position after assuming an upright 
posture. Although there has been a marked improvement 
in the variability of perioperative circulatory dynamics in 
patients with pheochromocytoma through the develop ment of perioperative management guidelines, it is still 
crucial to carefully monitor circulatory dynamics during 
early mobilization and after completion.
